title: 109_s660
content: The "Lumbee Recognition Act" is the short title of this Act. The preamble of the Act of June 7, 1956 is amended by making specific changes to the wording. The Lumbee Indians of North Carolina, recognized by the state since 1885 and by Congress in 1956, seek full Federal recognition and the associated benefits. Federal recognition is extended to the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina, allowing them to receive all laws and regulations applicable to Indians and Indian tribes. Any group of Indians in specific counties in North Carolina not enrolled in the Lumbee Tribe may petition for acknowledgment of tribal existence. Eligibility for services and benefits is also addressed. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina and its members are eligible for services and benefits provided to federally recognized Indian tribes. Members residing in specific counties are considered to be on or near a reservation. The Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Health and Human Services will determine needs and budget for services in consultation with the tribe. The Secretaries of the Interior and Health and Human Services will submit budget requests to Congress based on the needs of the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina after verifying the tribal roll. The tribal roll will define the service population of the Tribe and must comply with membership criteria set in the Tribe's constitution. Verification will be completed within one year of the enactment of this section. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina seeks to convey fee land to the United States for trust purposes within Robeson County, North Carolina. The Secretary of the Interior will treat the land as on-reservation trust acquisitions. Additionally, state jurisdiction is addressed in the following section. The State of North Carolina has jurisdiction over criminal offenses and civil actions on land owned by the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina. The Secretary of the Interior can accept jurisdiction transfers from the state under an agreement with the tribe. This section does not affect the Indian Child Welfare Act. "Authorization of appropriations for carrying out this Act."
